titlestmt.titleproper: Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Homes, Series I
A Guide to the Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Homes, Series I FA318

did.unittitle: Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Homes, Series I

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Material in the Rockefeller family collections that provides the names, correspondence, or activities of living members of the Rockefeller family, and/or documents the net wealth of any Rockefeller family members, is restricted. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records are arranged by subject matter in 27 series. Most of these series are wholly or partially open for research. The series are:

A John D. Rockefeller, Sr.; C Business Interests; D Civic Interests; E Cultural Interests; F Economic Reform Interests; G Educational Interests; H Friends and Services; I Homes; J Housing Interests; K Medical Interests; L Real Estate; M Maps and Memorabilia; N Religious Interests; O Rockefeller Boards; P Welfare - General Files; Q World Affairs; R Welfare - Youth Files; S Documents; T Public Relations; U Public Land Law Review Commission; V Greenrock; W Properties; X Costume Collection; Y Media; Z John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Personal; AA Abby Aldrich Rockefeller; AC Abby Rockefeller Mauz√©

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The central figure in the creation and operation of the Standard Oil Company during its rise to the top of the petroleum industry, John D. Rockefeller (JDR) established for the family a leading role in business and philanthropy. From the days of his earliest employment, Rockefeller, a devout Baptist, was generous in his giving to worthy causes, especially those of a religious nature. During the 1890s he developed an orderly system of philanthropic giving through an office staff that included his close advisor, Frederick T. Gates (1853-1929) and his son, John D. Rockefeller, Jr. (1874-1960). With the advise of these and other associates, Rockefeller established the University of Chicago, The Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research (now The Rockefeller University), the Rockefeller Foundation, and other philanthropic organizations working nationally and internationally in the fields of education, religion, and health. Rockefeller's total donations to philanthropic endeavors are estimated to have been $540 million.

John D. Rockefeller, Jr. (JDR Jr.) joined his father's office on October 1, 1897. He oversaw the expansion and diversification of the philanthropic work begun by his father. During his lifetime, the younger Rockefeller gave more than $537 million to educational, religious, cultural, medical, and other charitable projects.

John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and his wife, Abby Aldrich Rockefeller (1874-1948), passed the Rockefeller philanthropic impulse on to their children. John D. 3rd (1906-1978), Nelson A. (1908-1979), Laurance S. (1910-2004), Winthrop (1912-1973), and David (1915-) further expanded and diversified Rockefeller influence and interests, establishing their own philanthropic organizations, most notably the Rockefeller Brothers Fund (1940), and becoming more active politically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller (OMR) materials document the increasing role assumed by John D. Rockefeller, Jr. in the management of Rockefeller affairs and amply document his business and philanthropic affairs. They also chronicle the entrance of JDR Jr.'s sons, John D. 3rd, Nelson A., Laurance S., Winthrop, and David, into the world of business, philanthropy, civic leadership, and politics as they joined the office.

This material contains correspondence, reports, pamphlets, memoranda, deeds, maps, contracts, reports, minutes, charters, certificates of incorporation, clippings, diaries, notebooks, calendars, and memorabilia.
There is a microfilm card index of personal and institutional names.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in thirteen subseries, as follows:

Transfer of Property, Florida Property, Lakewood Property, 740 Park Avenue Apartment, Richford Property, Pocantico Hills, Seal Harbor, 10 West 54th Street, 4 West 54th Street, 12 West 54th Street, One Beekman Place, Hills Realty Company, Inc., House Books. Some oversized material has been separated and placed at the end of the collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Homes series documents the management of four of John D. Rockefeller, Sr.'s and John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s estates and their New York City homes. The estates are Ormond Beach, Florida; Lakewood, New Jersey; Pocantico Hills, New York; and Seal Harbor, Maine. The New York City homes are 4, 10, and 12 West 54th Street and the apartment at 740 Park Avenue. There is also information regarding John D. Rockefeller 3rd's apartment at One Beekman Place. Most of the material deals with property purchases, employees, the construction of homes, out buildings, and private roads, relations with neighbors and local communities, the contents of the houses (particularly art collections), and the general maintenance and operation of the various homes. The correspondence is between members of the family and the family office on the one hand, and estate managers, employees, contractors, real estate agents, neighbors, members of the various communities, and art dealers on the other.

The Homes series is divided into twelve sections, nine concern the homes listed above, and three others concern Richford; Transfer of Property; and House Books. The Richford section contains information on the purchase of the site of John D. Rockefeller, Sr.'s birthplace and surrounding property in the 1920s to prevent its commercial exploitation. The Transfer of Property section concerns the transfer of ownership of the various estates from John D. Rockefeller, Sr. to his son John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and the distribution of John D. Rockefeller, Sr.'s personal effects after his death. The House Books are listings and descriptions of the contents of the various houses. These lists also include the contents of Bassett Hall at Williamsburg, Virginia, and John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s office at Room 5600. Also included in these books are distributions of the personal effects of John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Abby Aldrich Rockefeller, and Martha Baird Rockefeller after their respective deaths.

Aside from offering an insight into the management of the family estates and homes, this series also illustrates John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s personal interests in the conservation of land and wildlife and in collecting Chinese porcelains and other art objects. The series also gives many examples of the attention he gave to the details in every affair he handled.

The collection measures 98 cubic feet. The material covers the years 1885-1961, and the family members who figure prominently in the papers are John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and John D. Rockefeller 3rd. John D. Rockefeller, Sr., Abby Aldrich Rockefeller, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Winthrop Rockefeller, Laurance S. Rockefeller, and David Rockefeller also appear. Of the Rockefeller family advisors who appear, Robert W. Gumbel and Charles O. Heydt are the most prominent.

Richford Property - Birthplace (Shea)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposal to exhibit John D. Rockefeller's alledged birthplace at Coney Island. Efforts to ship it. John D. Rockefeller's efforts to stop exhibition. Purchase of land around homestead to prevent exploitation. Failure to obtain land owned by S. Deneen who had made initial proposal. Tax sale of land. Questions about actual birthplace. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Thomas M. Debevoise, Lillian Willcox.

Pocantico Hills - New House and Gardens - George Gray Barnard - Adam and Eve

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Negotiations delay. Sargent's artistic comments. Barnard's comments on his work. Construction of setting for work. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s impatience at Barnard's slow work. Barnard's financial problems. Antagonism between Barnard and Bosworth. Readjustment of contract. Sent to Pocantico Hills in 1923. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. paid Barnard extra at finish to make final cost of work $75,000. Casting and base and protection raised cost to $99,728.82. Repair and upkeep. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., W. W. Bosworth, George Gray Barnard, J. Sargent.

did.unittitle: Pocantico Hills - New House and Gardens - Miscellaneous

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Trouble with tenants and laborers. Accidents. Estate repair. Proposed incorporation of Pocantico. Proposed annexation to North Tarrytown. Use of bridle paths by neighbors. No publicity on mode of living of Rockefeller family policy. Scrap campaign, 1942. Request to photograph, rent house, use pasture land, etc. Threats from R. Gulich, lady who wants John D. Rockefeller, Jr. to take action against re-zoning. Correspondents include W. C. Briggs, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Dyson F. DeLap, A. J. Bartlett, Robert W. Gumbel, Charles O. Heydt.

did.unittitle: Pocantico Hills - New House and Gardens - Release of Coal for Pocantico Hills

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: World War I coal shortage. John D. Rockefeller had excess supply on land. Fuel administrator asked him to share. John D. Rockefeller sold some to Ossining dealers, sold more to tenants and employees at Pocantico Hills. Pricing of coal led to bad publicity. Rockefellers gave profit of coal sales to Lyceum and two churches in Pocantico Hills. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Charles O. Heydt.

did.unittitle: Pocantico Hills - New House and Gardens - Sewers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Placing of monuments by Sanitary Commission on Rockefeller land. Permission by John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Considers making gift of sewer system to Pocantico. New sewer connections to main line. Agreement between John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and Board of Water and Sewer Commission. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. pays Board $2,000 per year for services, agrees to pay $5,000 toward sanitary sewer under aqueduct. Opinion concerning water and sewer system. Sewer system permit, 1931, cost $25,711.53. Correspondents include Thomas M. Debevoise, William J. Yates, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Joseph Reeback.

Pocantico Hills - Property - Christian Brothers Property

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In 1909, the Brothers needed money for interest on mortgage. Discussed sale of some land to John D. Rockefeller. Small sale concluded in 1910. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. concerned about sewage from school draining into Pocantico River. Sale of small parcels of the Brothers' lands continues. In 1928, John D. Rockefeller, Jr. approached Brothers offering to buy entire site. Deal made in April 1928; John D. Rockefeller, Jr. paid $1,800,000. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Charles O. Heydt, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

Rockefeller, Jr. approached Brothers offering to buy entire site. Deal made in April 1928; John D. Rockefeller, Jr. paid $1,800,000. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Charles O. Heydt, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: Pocantico Hills - Property - Survey - C. W. Leavitt

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Charles Wellford Leavitt and Son (surveyors) commissioned in February 1928 to conduct contour survey and map of 3,000 acre Rockefeller estate in Pocantico Hills, NY. Survey completed by March 1929. Resulting topographic maps were numbered #1728-R, sheets 1-11, and #1728 Index sheet. Correspondents include Charles O. Heydt, Charles Wellford Leavitt, and Arthur Miller (Walter Kidde Constructors).

did.unittitle: Pocantico Hills - Property - Survey by Lawyers - Title and Guaranty

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A disagreement with a neighbor over lines leads to a complete survey and title search of Rockefeller estate in Pocantico Hills. Lawyers Title and Guaranty Company commissioned in March 1930 to survey boundaries of the estate. Survey conducted by Earl B. Lovell, Chief Surveyor for Lawyers Title and Guaranty Company. Setting of boundary monuments completed by April 1933. Estate boundaries marked by 931 cement and copper monuments bearing the initials J.D.R. Jr., and the monument's identification number. "Map of Property Belonging to John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Situated at Pocantico Hills, Westchester County, New York", sections 1-7 produced by Lovell. Some titles cleared of defects. Search for heirs to partial interests conducted, and family histories of previous owners produced. Correspondents include Charles O. Heydt, Thomas M. Debevoise, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Earl B. Lovell.

did.unittitle: Pocantico Hills - Property - Survey by Lawyers - Title and Guaranty

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A disagreement with a neighbor over lines leads to a complete survey and title search of Rockefeller estate in Pocantico Hills. Lawyers Title and Guaranty Company commissioned in March 1930 to survey boundaries of the estate. Survey conducted by Earl B. Lovell, Chief Surveyor for Lawyers Title and Guaranty Company. Setting of boundary monuments completed by April 1933. Estate boundaries marked by 931 cement and copper monuments bearing the initials J.D.R. Jr., and the monument's identification number. "Map of Property Belonging to John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Situated at Pocantico Hills, Westchester County, New York", sections 1-7 produced by Lovell. Some titles cleared of defects. Search for heirs to partial interests conducted, and family histories of previous owners produced. Correspondents include Charles O. Heydt, Thomas M. Debevoise, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Earl B. Lovell.

did.unittitle: Pocantico Hills - Roads - Bedford Road

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bedford Road dangerous. Fatal accident near estate leads to relocation of road. Rockefeller asked to finance work giving jobs to local unemployed. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. refused to bear entire burden himself. Offered to assume one-half. Politics involved since relocation of road involved North Tarrytown and Pleasantville. Correspondents include Thomas M. Debevoise, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Nelson A. Rockefeller, Charles O. Heydt.

Seal Harbor - Acadia Corporation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Organized to provide buildings for concessions in Acadia National Park. Refreshment stand on Cadillac Mountain Expansion. National Park policies on concessions. Jay Downer's long range program. Tavern taken over by U.S. Army during war. Reopening after war. Damages paid by Government. Other concessions operated. Opposition to Fair Labor Standards Act. Success of operation. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Grosvenor Atterbury, Jay Downer, David Rodick, Charles Savage.

Family contributions, gifts. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Malcolm Dana, Richard Smith, K. J. Strong, Charles Savage, Hollis M. Smith.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Clubs - Harbor Club

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Edsel Ford and John D. Rockefeller, Jr. establish club. Provide financing. Company formed to hold club called Bracey Cove Land Company. John D. Rockefeller 3rd represented his father legally but John D. Rockefeller, Jr. remained very interested in club facilities. Membership. Maintenance. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and Edsel Ford owned the club, made up annual deficits. In 1942 club closed for war. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. bought out Edsel Ford's interest in 1944. Reopened in 1946 with Nelson A. Rockefeller and David Rockefeller taking responsibility, leasing club from John D. Rockefeller, Jr. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. made gifts to club to assist in extraordinary expenditures. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Edsel Ford, Ernest Kanzler, Nelson A. Rockefeller, David Rockefeller, John J. O'Brien.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Garden at Eyrie

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Garden built especially around Korean figures. Beatrix Farrand supervised the work. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. kept close watch. Soil brought in, seeded each year. Changes in garden. This is the Chinese or Oriental Garden. Water supply. Visitors. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s intense careful interest in the garden. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Beatrix Farrand, Abby Aldrich Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Hancock County Trustees of Public Reservations

scopecontent.p: Organization created nucleus of Acadia National Park. Formed in 1901. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. worked through it in early years. Short history of organization. Contribution to memorial for George B. Dorr. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. felt it should disband when national park was realized. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Maine Biological Laboratories

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two biological stations on Mt. Dessert. One connected with University of Maine, one an outgrowth of Tufts College. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. made contributions to older (Tufts) station, sought a way to combine the two. Combination unsuccessful. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. became principal contributor to laboratory. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Arthur Woods, Arthur W. Packard, A. C. Bumpus.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Maine Sea Coast Missionary Society

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. made small annual donations to society from 1908. Society worked among fishermen and their families. Gave $2,000 toward cost of new boat. Eventually increased to $1,000 a year. Stopped without explanation in 1933. John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Nelson A. Rockefeller, and Davison Fund contributions. Continued by Martha Baird Rockefeller. Printed reports. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Willard S. Richardson, J. H. Nelson, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Martha Baird Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

Small contributions on nonrecurring basis. 1914 letter giving reason for Nelson A. Rockefeller's birth in Bar Harbor. Friends in Mt. Desert. Deaths. Comments on beauty of island. did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - National Park - George B. Dorr

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Superintendent of National Park. Worked with John D. Rockefeller, Jr. in planning roads on island. Dorr managed cutting of trees on public lands, received John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s permission to travel over private roads to bring it out. Many details on planning the roads. Dorr held land in his name which John D. Rockefeller, Jr. purchased. Dorr was moving spirit behind first park plans for Mt. Desert Island. Dorr's history of beginning of park. Death. Tributes. Will. Care of his homestead as part of park. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., George B. Dorr.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - National Park - George B. Dorr

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Superintendent of National Park. Worked with John D. Rockefeller, Jr. in planning roads on island. Dorr managed cutting of trees on public lands, received John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s permission to travel over private roads to bring it out. Many details on planning the roads. Dorr held land in his name which John D. Rockefeller, Jr. purchased. Dorr was moving spirit behind first park plans for Mt. Desert Island. Dorr's history of beginning of park. Death. Tributes. Will. Care of his homestead as part of park. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., George B. Dorr.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - National Park - Eagle Lake Tea House

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Construction of tea house. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s attention to details. Water supply for Bar Harbor problems. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Grosvenor Atterbury.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - National Park - Eagle Lake Tea House - Sanitation Reports and Restrictions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Studies of drainage from tea house to protect Bar Harbor Water Supply.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - National Park - Eagle Lake Tea House - Dr. Kast Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bar Harbor doctor favors Rockefeller plan, supports chlorinating plant for water supply.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - National Park - Eagle Lake Tea House - Transfer of Land for Site

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Between John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and Public Reservation to provide for tea house.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - National Park - Road Controversy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Opposition to building of carriage roads through new section of park. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. decides to stop building roads in view of such opposition, even if it is a minority voice. Surge of support for John D. Rockefeller, Jr. from many residents of the area. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., George Pepper, George B. Dorr.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Neighborhood Hall Association

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Organized to promote social welfare of community. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. a stockholder and contributor to organization. Built hall for motion pictures, dances, meetings. Annual contributions, $100, $300. Also called Seal Harbor Community Hall Association. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave his stock to Nelson A. Rockefeller in 1943. Turned over to Village Corporation in 1950. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Dr. Edward K. Dunham, George L. Stebbins, Nelson A. Rockefeller, David Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Neighborhood Hall Association - Contributions by John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s Sons

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: By John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Laurance S. Rockefeller, Nelson A. Rockefeller, David Rockefeller, $25 a year.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Neighborhood Hall Association - Voting Trust

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Nelson A. Rockefeller cooperates in plan to consolidate control of corporation.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Neighborhood Hall Association

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Organized to promote social welfare of community. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. a stockholder and contributor to organization. Built hall for motion pictures, dances, meetings. Annual contributions, $100, $300. Also called Seal Harbor Community Hall Association. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave his stock to Nelson A. Rockefeller in 1943. Turned over to Village Corporation in 1950. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Dr. Edward K. Dunham, George L. Stebbins, Nelson A. Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Northeast Harbor - General

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s interest in improvements in Northeast Harbor. Nelson A. Rockefeller's participation in Harbor Club. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Nelson A. Rockefeller, David Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Northeast Harbor - Dances

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s contributions to support of weekly dances.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Northeast Harbor - Golf Club

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gives one quarter cost of expansion in 1922, made other small contributions. Donated stock to treasury.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Northeast Harbor - Contributions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: To annual fire department dance, Sunday Evening Club, Neighborhood House, Union Church, Library. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Nelson A. Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Northeast Harbor - Contributions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondents include David Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Northeast Harbor - Harbor Dredging Project

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 1939 attempt to set up Northeast Port Authority to dredge harbor with funding powers opposed by John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and others. Compromise attempts using federal funds and contributions. Failure. 1953 federal program for improving harbor. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Nelson A. Rockefeller, G. H. Montague, Edward K. Dunham.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Northeast Harbor - Park and Road Project

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plan to improve beach areas and roads in Northeast Harbor. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. subscribed $50,000 to project. Entire plan opposed by local residents. Voted down. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gift never made. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Otter Creek Bridge - Charter

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Revision of 1889 charter so that private bridge could be built.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Otter Creek Bridge

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plans to replace bridge over inlet. Negotiations with government. Delays. Original bridge built by company organized in 1889. Land transferred to national park, bridge finally built by U. S. Government. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Arno B. Cammerer.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Otter Creek Bridge - Otter Creek Bridge Company

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Purchased by John D. Rockefeller, Jr. when land bought. Kept active to build bridge. Dissolved when government built bridge instead.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Property - Purchase of "Eyrie"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Purchase of Clarke property (The Eyrie) by John D. Rockefeller, Jr. in 1910. Through George L. Stebbins. Work on Eyrie in winter of 1910. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. contributions to purchase of land for public reservation. Purchase of additional land at Seal Harbor. Details of purchases, transfers of title. Purchases of land both personal and for the National Park. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., George L. Stebbins, Robert F. DeRevere, M. L. Caston, Charles K. Savage, Robert W. Gumbel, C. T. Keppel.

Seal Harbor - Public Reservations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In 1911, Stebbins invited John D. Rockefeller, Jr. to join in purchase of lands as public reservation. His first contribution was $100. In 1914, Dorr promoted larger plan. Gift of reservation to federal government as monument. Made national park in 1919. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s road plans. Correspondents include George B. Dorr, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., George L. Stebbins.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Radio Station

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. requests government to consider moving radio station to preserve beauty of proposed road. Plan studied by naval officials. Sent to Congress for action. Station moved from Otter Creek to Schoodic Point in 1933. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Horace M. Albright, Arthur Woods, Arno B. Cammerer.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Realty Company

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr., and other Seal Harbor friends form realty company, to handle purchases and sales in their interest. George L. Stebbins was the largest stockholder. In 1926, John D. Rockefeller, Jr. bought up entire company. Discussion of land owned by company. Changes in directors. Correspondents include Edward K. Dunham, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., George L. Stebbins, Serenus B. Rodick, Charles O. Heydt, Robert W. Gumbel.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Richardson Farm

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Search for safe milk supply for summer residents. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. offers to aid milk producer financially to ensure proper conditions. Fire destroys equipment. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and others lend further funds. Edward K. Dunham and others financed sanitary dairy farm on island. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. assumed some of the debt. Richardson, the farmer, had difficulty paying off debt. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and other creditors made several adjustments in principal. Debt finally paid off. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Edward K. Dunham, Mrs. Edward K. Dunham, P. S. Richardson, D. H. McAlpin.

Rockefeller, Jr., Edward K. Dunham, Mrs. Edward K. Dunham, P. S. Richardson, D. H. McAlpin.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Relocation of Reef Point Plants

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. financed transfer of Beatrix Farrand's gardens at Reef Point to Asticou Terrace and Thuya lodge area. Also work on roads to Thuya Lodge. Payments completed by Estate. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Charles K. Savage.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Roads - General

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. made first subscription toward road building in 1913. Gave $250 to George L. Stebbins. Also began his own extension road work that year. Stebbins supervised early road work for John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Gradual extension of road network. Relations with builders, local authorities. Comments on roads. Cooperation with National Park authorities. Letters of appreciation for roads. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., George L. Stebbins, Charles O. Heydt, George B. Dorr, Paul Simpson, Charles K. Savage.

Rockefeller, Jr.'s concern that political considerations may interrupt Rodick's work with Acadia National Park. Hancock County Civilian Defense contribution. Mr. Desert fire. Rodick's death. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Serenus B. Rodick, George L. Stebbins, G. L. Montague.

did.unittitle: Seal Harbor - Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory, Bar Harbor, Maine

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Research and supply laboratory for cancer, other diseases. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s interest, aid. Family contributions. In 1947, fire destroys buildings, records. Newspaper coverage results in federal grant, many gifts. In 1948, Rockefeller Foundation contributions amounted to $85,000. Report, "The Need for Endowment to Insure Continuous and Effective Basic Research." Correspondents include Laurance S. Rockefeller, David Rockefeller, Nelson A. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Clarence C. Little.

odd.head: General note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The making of color pictures of John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s porcelain collection. His concern with detail. Delays in work. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s dissatisfaction with some of the pictures. Reworking by Color Plate Engraving Company. Insistence on exact color conformity of photos with objects. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. purchased 25 copies of each plate.

did.unittitle: 10 West 54th Street - Rugs - Duty on Antique Rugs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arthur U. Pope begins campaign to lower tariff on antique rugs. Report to John D. Rockefeller, Jr. on progress. No success as friends in Congress refuse to open tariff question there. Dragged on for several years. B. J. Sloan opposed revision violently. Finally passed in 1930 allowing rugs made before 1700 into country duty free.

did.unittitle: 10 West 54th Street - Rugs - Polonaise Rugs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. interested in acquiring such rugs and made inquiries. Started run on Polonaise rugs. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. bought three rugs from Duveen for $129,000. Bought two more from Duveen in 1923 for $82,000. Bought two more from Parish-Watson in 1927. Bought more in 1928.

did.unittitle: 10 West 54th Street - Rugs - Arthur U. Pope - Sarre Rug

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arthur U. Pope bought Sarre rug in Paris. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. agreed to buy it from him in America at a fixed price later on. Rug repaired in Paris at John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s expense. It was a Persian animal carpet. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. guaranteed $40,000 loan so that Pope could buy the rug. Delivered to New York in 1927. Discussion of Pope's commission. Pope was an advisor to Philadelphia Museum.

Rockefeller, Jr. distributes furniture from 4 West 54th Street to family after purchasing it from his father. Keebler urges immediate (1936) demolition to cut taxes. House demolished, 1937, to provide Abby Aldrich Rockefeller with bricks for home at Pocantico. Correspondents include Charles O. Heydt, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Robert W. Gumbel.

did.unittitle: Hills Realty Company, Inc. - Hills Western Company, Inc. - Corporate Documents
House Books

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The House Books document the contents and distribution of several properties and collections of John D. Rockefeller Jr, his wives, and his children. The House Books are scrapbooks, inventories, and guidebooks to a wide range of artworks and belongings, organized by different houses owned by the Family. The Housebooks contains information concerning: the Chinese Porcelains collection, Kykuit and the Kykuit Playhouse, Bassett Hall, John D. Rockefeller Jr's Office, the Eyrie and Eyrie Playhouse, Hillcrest, distributions to his children and family members, and distributions to museums.

The Housebooks consists of approximately 9,325 pages, approximately 437 negatives and a card file. Among the pages are photographs (both color and black & white), note cards, gallery catalogue pages, newspaper and magazine clippings, brief biographies of artists, appraisals, memos and correspondence, excerpts from books, inventories, quotes, receipts, certificates of authenticity, estimates, building permits and building plans.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The House Books are loosely arranged by property, with folders arranged following the original order of the bound volumes with which the materials were original received. Within these folders are pictures of each of the pieces, typically organized by category (for example: the binders for each of the houses contained tabs such as "rugs" or "ornaments", followed by information for all of the rugs or ornaments for that given property. Examples of categories include (but are not necessarily limited to): brass, candlesticks, ceramics, china, clocks, figures, flatware, furniture, glassware, lamps, misc, ornaments, pictures, sculpture, silver, or textiles. The documentation often includes (but is not necessarily limited to): pictures, location information, a brief description of the item, dimensions, place of purchase or appraisal, purchase price, date of purchase, gallery catalogue listings, and other information.

A large portion of the Housebooks pertains to distributions, with the first portion of the Distributions organized by dates (folders 1634-1639). The second portion of the Distributions is divided by the recipient of the items. The third portion of the "Distributions" is organized by appraisal number at the Parke-Bernet Gallery. The fourth portion of the "Distributions" binders is divided by the recipient. The fifth and final portion of the "Distributions" binders is organized by category (e.g. paintings, porcelains, and jewelry).

did.unittitle: Negatives, Personal Property at Hillcrest

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Negatives are individually notated. (For example: each of the negatives has a label with a letter‚Äîexplained by the key‚Äîand a number‚Äîto denote each negatives' place in the original order). The negatives are arranged alpha-numerically by their letter-number designation (for example: A12 precedes B1). There are several alpha-codes within the key that are not represented in the records (for example: there are no negatives labeled "F" which denotes Sofas), nor are the numbers always perfectly sequential (for example: there is no negative in the collection labeled D4, but there is a negative labeled D5). Several negatives may have the same label, but depict different objects (for example: there are four negatives labeled G18). Finally, there are several numbers that are represented by note cards or photographs instead of negatives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Master Card file is comprised of index cards with images and details about John D. Rockefeller Jr's extensive porcelain collection. A key is available on site at RAC which provides notations used to denote the individual items.
